title: Ottawa Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) Rule for Headache Evaluation
description: Clinical decision rule to identify alert patients with acute headache who are at risk for subarachnoid hemorrhage. This validated tool has 100% sensitivity for ruling out SAH but should not be used alone to diagnose SAH due to low specificity (15.3%). Designed to guide decision-making for CT scanning and further investigation in emergency department patients.

parameters.name: neck_pain_stiffness
parameters.description: Complaint of neck pain or neck stiffness

scoring.yes: Neck pain or stiffness present (positive criterion)
scoring.no: No neck pain or stiffness (negative criterion)

parameters.name: witnessed_loss_of_consciousness
parameters.description: Witnessed loss of consciousness at time of headache onset

scoring.no: No witnessed loss of consciousness (negative criterion)

parameters.name: onset_during_exertion
parameters.description: Headache onset during exertion (physical activity, straining, sexual activity)

parameters.name: thunderclap_headache
parameters.description: Thunderclap headache (instantly peaking pain reaching maximum intensity immediately)

parameters.name: limited_neck_flexion
parameters.description: Limited neck flexion on examination (inability to touch chin to chest or flex neck due to pain)

scoring.yes: Limited neck flexion on examination (positive criterion)

result.name: ottawa_sah_result
result.description: Rule result indicating whether subarachnoid hemorrhage can be ruled out based on Ottawa SAH criteria

ranges.interpretation: All criteria negative - SAH can be ruled out with 100% sensitivity. No further testing required specifically for SAH.
One or more criteria positive - SAH cannot be ruled out. Further investigation with CT scan (within 6 hours) or lumbar puncture recommended.

references: Perry JJ, Stiell IG, Sivilotti ML, Bullard MJ, Emond M, Symington C, et al. Sensitivity of computed tomography performed within six hours of onset of headache for diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage: prospective cohort study. BMJ. 2011;343:d4277. doi: 10.1136/bmj.d4277.

Perry JJ, Stiell IG, Sivilotti ML, Bullard MJ, Lee JS, Eisenhauer M, et al. High risk clinical characteristics for subarachnoid haemorrhage in patients with acute headache: prospective cohort study. BMJ. 2010;341:c5204. doi: 10.1136/bmj.c5204.

Perry JJ, Sivilotti ML, Sutherland J, Hohl CM, Émond M, Calder LA, et al. Validation of the Ottawa Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Rule in patients with acute headache. CMAJ. 2017;189(45):E1379-E1385. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.170072.
formula: Ottawa SAH Rule = Assessment of 6 criteria: Age ≥40 years + Neck pain/stiffness + Witnessed LOC + Onset with exertion + Thunderclap headache + Limited neck flexion
notes: Rule has 100% sensitivity for subarachnoid hemorrhage but low specificity (15.3%)
Designed as a rule-out tool - negative result can safely exclude SAH
Any positive criterion means SAH cannot be ruled out and further investigation is needed
Application criteria: Alert patients ≥15 years, new severe atraumatic headache, maximum intensity within 1 hour, presenting within 14 days
Exclusion criteria: New neurologic deficits, prior aneurysm/SAH/brain tumor, chronic recurrent headaches
Validated in multiple studies with over 4,000 patients
Recommended workup for positive result: Non-contrast CT within 6 hours, consider LP if high suspicion
The rule should not be used to diagnose SAH due to low specificity
Original derivation study included 2,131 patients with 132 cases of SAH
External validation confirmed 100% sensitivity across multiple studies
Clinical impact: Reduces unnecessary imaging while maintaining safety
